importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The main Diwali day in 2025 falls on October 20, marking the celebration of the festival of lights across South Asia and diaspora communities worldwide.
Sikhs commemorate Bandi Chhor Divas on October 21, marking the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 Hindu kings from imprisonment, a significant moment in Sikh history and human rights.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The five-day Diwali festival spans from October 20 to October 25, creating a cultural and communal time frame of celebration, renewal, and shared traditions.

keyTakeAways: Diwali is a festival of light, community, and fresh starts, celebrated by over a billion people across religious and cultural lines.
The festival marks the triumph of light over darkness, good over evil, and is rooted in myths from the Ramayana, Krishna legends, and Jain/Buddhist traditions.
Diwali is celebrated over five days: Dhanteras, Choti Diwali, Diwali (Lakshmi Puja), Padwa, and Bhai Dooj, each with unique traditions and symbolism.
The festival transcends religion, being observed by Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists, and increasingly by people of all faiths and backgrounds.
Sikhs celebrate Bandi Chhor Divas on October 21, commemorating the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings, reflecting historical and human rights significance.
For Jains, Diwali marks the attainment of enlightenment by Lord Mahavira; for Buddhists, it marks Emperor Ashoka’s embrace of Buddhism.
Diwali is a time for financial renewal, with businesses opening new accounts, and for cultural expression through diyas, rangoli, sweets, and family gatherings.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diwali, the festival of lights, is celebrated by over a billion people across the world, including Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists. It marks the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil, with deep roots in mythological stories such as Rama’s return from exile, Krishna’s defeat of Narakasura, and the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings by Sikhs. The festival spans five days, each with unique traditions: Dhanteras (buying gold and home cleaning), Choti Diwali (Krishna’s victory), Diwali (Lakshmi Puja and family feasts), Padwa (husband-wife bond), and Bhai Dooj (sibling love). Celebrations include lighting diyas, rangoli, fireworks, and feasting. Diwali also symbolizes the beginning of the new Hindu financial year and is celebrated globally in South Asia and diaspora communities in countries like Malaysia, Nepal, and Fiji. Its significance extends beyond religious observance, representing cultural unity, community, renewal, and shared human values of justice, liberation, and prosperity.
title: It’s Diwali, a time for light, community and fresh starts
